clinicalDescription: Overview: PAH. Rare, chronic, progressive disorder characterized by high blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs (pulmonary artery) for no apparent reason. Causes the walls of the lungs arteries to tighten and stiffen. Leads to heart failure. Presentation: Shortness of breath, fatigue, dizziness, cough, and chest pressure - symptoms get worse over time Assessment: Hard to dx; Echo (check pressure in the pulmonary arteries), Ventilation-perfusion scan (V/Q scan), EKG, CXR, right heart catheterization, pulmonary function tests Plan: Improve breathing. O2 therapy, anticoagulants, calcium channel blockers, prostaglandins, possible for a lung transplant or septostomy. Heritable PAH is confirmed if two or more family members have PAH or if a BMPR2 gene mutation or mutation in another gene known to cause PAH is identified in the affected person. Prognosis: Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong. Life-threatening condition that gets worse over time, but treatments can help the symptoms.
